p: We showed previously that TMPRSS2 is required for H1 cleavage activation in vivo ( 13). Tmprss2 −/− mutant mice are completely protected from mortality after infection with several H1N1 and H7N9 viruses ( 13, 14, 32). In addition, infection with 10 FFU of A/HK/01/68 (H3N2) virus, which also carries a monobasic cleavage site in HA, resulted in less body weight loss and lower mortality for Tmprss2 −/− mice than for wild-type mice. However, this difference was less pronounced after infection with an increased virus dose. Therefore, we investigated whether a further protease may be involved in cleavage activation of H3N2 viruses.
